Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Efficient Spectrum Allocation Auctions in Secondary Markets with Dynamic Random Supply and Demand

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing spectrum demand from wireless applications cannot be satisfied with existing fixed spectrum allocation techniques. To provide dynamic spectrum access, auction based spectrum trading has received considerable attention. In spectrum trading, licensed users rent their unused spectrum to unlicensed users in exchange for money. The availability of unused spectrum depends on the usage pattern of licensed users and varies over time, frequency, and spatial domain. Unlicensed users can bid for this spectrum according to their needs which again vary by time and location. Thus, the auction scenario has to deal with the dynamic user demand and dynamic spectrum supply. Existing research on spectrum trading consider either a static auction environment or at most one side of the dynamics of the auction environment. Therefore, for improving spectrum unitization, it is critical to consider an auction scenario where bidders with heterogeneous demand arrive dynamically and bid for dynamically available spectrum units.

This project studies a dynamic auction framework and undertakes the development of auction rules and regulations designed to achieve an efficient spectrum allocation. The study consists of four major components. (1) Developing the dynamic auction framework with dynamic arrival of users with variable lifetime and dynamic spectrum supply. (2) Tackling the design challenges associated with the diversity in demand and supply in terms of units and duration and devising a truthful auction mechanism. (3) Designing a generic auction framework to fit the auction rules and regulations and define the communication method using a secure communication protocol. (4) Developing a testbed to implement, experiment and validate the auction framework. This research will enhance radio spectrum sharing and utilization, providing more spectrum opportunities for existing and new applications. This project provides interdisciplinary research opportunities for graduate students working on the proposed research. This project incorporates research results into courses and to recruit students from underrepresented backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to address the issue that the current fixed frequency allocation approach will no longer be an efficient design for radio spectrum allocation to keep up with the substantial growth of spectrum demand in wireless broadband communications. In this project, we consider an auction scenario where bidders with heterogeneous demand arrive dynamically and bid for dynamically available spectrum units. We study these realistic auction scenarios and develop truthful and individual rational auction mechanism.

 We consider the secondary spectrum market with a dynamic auction setting where both the secondary users as bidders and spectrum units as auctioned items arrive dynamically at the auction. Each secondary user may have a different deadline to get the transmission opportunity and thus stays in the auction for a different duration. A secondary user sends its bid request including its delay bound and its valuation for the item without knowing the exact number of supplies and rival bidders, and leaves the auction as soon as it wins a spectrum unit in the auction or its deadline expires. A primary user joins the auction to lease its spare spectrum unit which becomes available on-the-fly. The auctioneer makes online spectrum allocation decisions by selecting winners and by determining the required payments by using a priority ranking algorithm. In situations that distribution knowledge of auction entities may not be readily available and the previous mechanism may suffer from inaccurate estimation of distribution parameters, consider the spectrum action problem in distributed free cases. We propose another online auction mechanism that does not require any distribution information. The mechanism applies bid monotonic spectrum allocation, periodic monitoring and critical price based payment adjustment to ensure truthful reporting of bidders.

We consider a practical spectrum trading scenario where primary users put their unused spectrum up for auction with a reserve price; secondary users with variable transmission deadlines arrive at the auction dynamically and submit their bids to win spectrum units. We model this setting as an online double auction and propose two algorithms for winner selection and price determination.  In the first algorithm, the auctioneer calculates the discounted option value of a bidder at different periods considering its winning opportunity at later periods before their deadlines. The discounted values of bidders are then matched against the asks of sellers to select winners and determine the payment amount. In the second algorithm, we introduce a bid-independent ?debt factor? that adjusts the payment amount of a winner depending on the number of users interfering with it over its lifetime. The users go through a candidate screening phase followed by a debt calculation phase, and finally winners are selected adhering to pricing rules in the algorithm.

While static trading mechanisms using auction are well understood, most transactions take place in a dynamic setting with changing demand and supply. The limitation of the received literature on trading is particularly prominent in markets that must allocate scarce resources in real time. This research focused on the problem of allocating  limited spectrum availability for real-time communications. Mechanisms were explored to determine priority rules for allocating spectrum to highest-valued users when future needs were uncertain and would be realized over time. The prioritization would discount current values by the option value of delay and determine the most efficient allocations, given the information constraints. This problem addresses needs in mobile telephony, but more importantly, also across other distributed systems, especially in the advent of the internet of things.

Because the issue of allocating scarce resources overtime has many applications, the insights also help inform other trading scenarios with similar features. Thus, in current extensions to the work, emissions trading (carbon offset trading) seems a particularly promising area to utilize some of the insights from this research as it will inform how to best balance policy needs concerning the environment with efficiency desires of industrial production. The applicability of the models may also carry over to other decentralized trading structures broadly encountered in e-commerce and the new economy.

The protocols and mechanisms developed for this project will find broader applications in many auction settings that have aspects of interdependency, barter and shifting participation across time. The findings have broader implications for other markets with dynamic trading under uncertain supply and demand, such as carbon emissions trading. The project works with students from underrepresented groups. Methods of the project are incorporated into the courses that the co-PIs teach. The project provides students with a platform to learn and understand the concept, research issues, and techniques for radio spectrum sharing. This project provides interdisciplinary research opportunities for graduate students working on the proposed research.
